# First Principles

Like many of you, I was in complete shock when I heard the news of the Capitol being broken into this past week. After incessantly refreshing New York Times every few minutes for updates, my shock transfigured into anger. I was angry that a peaceful protest highlighting racial injustice in July yielded hundreds of arrests in the first hour, but not a single arrest had been made in the first hour of a government building being seized. I was angry at the lack of leadership that we saw from our country's politicians. Even more so, I was angry at the divided America in which we live in today. An America that so clearly has one set of rules for white males and an entirely different set of rules for everyone else. 

![A Divided America](https://www.tc.columbia.edu/media/news/images/2020/march/istock_flag_art.jpg)
*(Image: iStock)*

This anger eventually led me to question the partisan America in which we live in today. Are our circumstances particulary unique due to the orangutan in office or was America always designed to be divided by the Founding Fathers? In an attempt to answer this question, I picked up the book *First Principles: What America's Founders Learned from the Greeks and Romans and How That Shaped Our Country* by Thomas E. Ricks. Through the course of the book, Ricks comprehensively highlights the experiences, education, and books which heavily influenced the first four presidents. It also brought to light something I believe is very applicable in today's world: our definition of democracy has been significantly influenced by great empires, but empires which have ultimately failed. For our democracy to not fail, we must continue to evolve it as to allow for greater participation, molding the vision of founding fathers to offer justice for **all** Americans. 

What I mean by this is that in the process of writing the two most influential documents outlining modern democracy, our founding fathers faced an inherent disconnect in the country that was *idealized* vs. the country they *realized*. This disconnect was partly due to the circumstances they were in -  uniting independent colonies while placating egregious demands to present an united front in the face of a common enemy. As such, the seeds of democracy were agreed upon by physically proximate yet idealogically disconnected states.
